metadata.title: Recreating the Gapminder Plot in PowerBI | by Kenneth Infante | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Recreating the Gapminder Plot in PowerBI
metadata.description: During the past weeks, I’ve seen a lot of analyses and visualizations on the impact of COVID19 on global health and the economy. More than an arm’s race to find a cure for the disease, it has also…

all_paragraphs: During the past weeks, I’ve seen a lot of analyses and visualizations on the impact of COVID19 on global health and the economy.
More than an arm’s race to find a cure for the disease, it has also spurred a lot of interest to data science as it applies to fight the pandemic.
And I’m going to jump in the bandwagon.

For a beginner, I think the perfect for this is the famous Gapminder graph by Professor Hans Rosling. Professor Rosling has done a fantastic job of telling a story using this plot and since then it has become the defacto beginner data visualization project.
Without further ado, let’s do the plot!
First, we have to get the data to be used in the visualization. You can download the data from the Gapminder website here or at my GitHub repo.
The data pertains to the following
Opening up the CSV files, you would notice that they are in the “wide” format (except for the Regions) like this
We have to convert our data to “long” or the “tidy” format to create the Gapminder plot.
Let’s start with the Life Expectancy data.
The data should now look like as follows
Repeat the above procedures for the Income and Population Data.
After doing so, the Income and Population Data should like as follows
The Region data is already in the “long” or “tidy” format but we have to format it further to do a merge later on.

The above creates a new column Subregion using Antarctica if the Country is Antarctica and the value of sub-region column otherwise. Do the same for Region column. Drop the old region and sub-region column afterward.
4. Finally, trim the Country column for trailing spaces
The Regions data should now look like this
The next step is to combine the Life Expectancy, Income, and Population data.
We have to do this for three reasons
Let’s start by combining our data.

We choose the Life Expectancy data first as it has the lowest number of rows. By choosing Left Join, the countries with no matching life expectancy will be removed in the resulting merge. This is to make sure that all countries have the life expectancy, income, and population once merging is done.
3. Expand the columns to include the Income per Person data.
Repeat the above process for the Population data. The data should look like as follows in the end
The resulting data has 186 rows and we can be sure that all countries have all the necessary fields as we use the Left Join earlier.
To make the trend more noticeable once we animate the data, let’s filter our Years column to a 5-year interval. We can do this with the Number.Mod function in PowerQuery
1. Create a new column as follows
2. Filter the custom column to include only 0 or the years divisible by 5. Remove the custom column afterward
The resulting data should now like as follows
Rename the combined data to Gapminder.
After all those preparations, we’re now finally ready to create our visualization.
To create the Gapminder plot.1. Drag and drop the Scatter to our PowerBI window. Resize as appropriate.
2. Drag the fields to appropriate axes in our plot
3. Let’s also colorized our Countries based on the Subregion. To do this, let’s create a relationship first between our Gapminder (merged) data and the Regions data.
Go to Modelling > Manage Relationships. Create a relationship as follows
Note that I chose to utilize relationships instead of merging the data as it’s not as messy as the previous process we did. The primary key for both data now is the Country column only.
4. Let’s format our chart to make it cleaner. Go to the Format pane and adjust the axes as follows
The final plot now looks like this
You can download the PowerBI here.
If you play this PowerBI from the years 1910 to 1920, you would notice that few dots have moved lower in 1920 compared to 1910 and 1915.
This is of course due to the Spanish Influenza that last 36 months from January 1918 to December 1920 infecting 500 million people — about a third of the world’s population at the time.
Will the COVID19 do the same for the year 2020?
We can’t tell and I’m hoping not. However, I’m excited to do recreate this plot once data for the year 2020 comes out.
Thank you for reading my article. Follow me on Twitter and Linkedin.
Check out also my book PowerQuery Guide to Pandas on Leanpub.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
